newsitem.title: USA: Study says black buying power rising rapidly.
newsitem.headline: Study says black buying power rising rapidly.

text.p: The purchasing power of black Americans has risen 54 percent in the past seven years, increasing more rapidly than inflation, researchers said Wednesday.
Black buying power is projected to reach $469 billion this year, a University of Georgia study said. The total is a 54 percent increase from the 1990 total of $304 billion.
The study said New York had the largest black market, followed by California, Texas, Illinois, Georgia, Florida, Maryland, Michigan, North Carolina and New Jersey.
Idaho showed the biggest increase in black buying power, followed by Utah, Nevada, New Mexico, Minnesota, Arizona, Oregon, Montana, Colorado and Wisconsin.

University of Georgia economic forecaster Jeff Humphreys said that in the fastest growing markets "the ability to capture black spending can make the difference between success and failure for many businesses."
